711226f-a.text:
East 14th Street, north side, east from Irving Place to Third Avenue, showing the (2nd) Academy of Music that was erected in 1867-8, Tammany Hall, or the Columbian Order (including the basement theatre of Tony Pastors'), and the Central Hotel. By 1940, the Consolidated Edison Company will have absorbed all of this land exclusive of the latter for their towering office building.
The melodrama "The Black Crook", playing at the formerly fashionable opera house, was the main attraction of the 1893 season.

1893

C.C. Langill, photo
Gift of Urbrook Collection
Credit Line Imperative
Neg No. 179

720616f.text:
Irving Place, east side, north from but not including East 14th Street, showing the executive offices of the Consolidated Gas Company (originally Manhattan Gas Company) at 4 Irving Place on the S.E. corner of 15th Street, and the clearing from 16th to 17th Streets where the Washington Irving High School for Girls is about to be built, replacing old 30-50 Irving Place. The Consolidated Gas Company building shown here was built before 1867. Before 1916 it will be superseded by a 20-story building on this site. About the same time 30-24 Irving Place, the house shown here at and adjoining the S.W. corner of 16th Street, will be replaced by a 13-story loft building.
On the S.E. corner of 18th Street may be seen the Huyler Chocolate
and Cocoa Factory.
March, 1909.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS

720617f-a.text:
Irving Place, east side, from 14th to 15th streets, showing the Academy of Music, with the Consolidated Gas offices at 4 Irving Place, on the SE corner of 15th street.  2 Irving Place used to be (around 1880) the home of the Lotus Club.

The Academy of Music, originally intended as a permanent home for Italian Opera, was opened on the side in October 1854, with a production of "Norms"  One of the notable performances in the old building was a concert at which Jenny Line sang.  On October 12th, 1860, a grand ball was given here for Edward (the future Edward VII) Prince of Wales, on the occasion of his visit to New York during his tour of North America.

The original Academy of Music, on this site, was burned May 22nd, 1866 and the building pictured here was opened the following February.  In 1887 the Academy Company decided not to compete further with the new and fashionable Metropolitan Opera House, and accordingly sold this building, after which it became a dramatic house.

As a legitimate theatre it was famous, among other things for the phenomenal run of "The Old Homestead" from August 30th 1888 to May 1891.  The elder Sothern and others also played for long runs.

On the afternoon of November 16th, 1919 the Prince of Wales, grandson of Edward VII, will pay the Academy a visit.  By that time it will have become a motion picture house.  Finally in 1926, it will be demolished and the gourd under the building will become part of the site of the new Consolidated Gas Building.

March 1909

720620f-a.text:
Irving Place, east side, north from but not including East 14th street, to, but not including East 18th street.  The view shows the old Consolidated Gas Company Building on the SE corner of 15th street.  In the distance is seen a clearness between 16th and 17th streets, where the Washington Irving High (Girls) will be erected.

March 1909

711228f-c.text:
(1)

East 14th Street, north side, east from Irving Place, to Third Ave.  The view shows the Academy of Music and the Olympic Theatre, with Tammany Hall occupying the same building.

May 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

(2)

The same, a view farther eastward.

May 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

(3)

The same, as No. 1 and showing Irving Place, at the N.E. corner of East 14th Street.  The Consolidated Gas Company Building is seen towering over the old Academy of Music.

May 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

711229f-a.text: 14th Street, north side, east from Irving Place, during the demolition of the old Tammany Hall building. August 4, 1928.

711225f-a.text:
14th Street, north side, from west of Irving Place to west of Avenue A.
1930.
Wurts Brothers.

720618f-a.text:
Irving Place, south from East 15th to 14th (where it terminates) Streets, showing prominently the City Theatre, which is on the south side, of East 14th Street, between Third and Fourth Aves.
September 2, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

720619f-a.text:
Irving Place, south from East 18th to 14th Streets. Towered building shown, is the Consolidated Gas Co. Building, and is located at the N.E. corner of 14th Street.
October 2, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

720625f-a.text:
Irving Place, east side, south from East 16th to East 14th Streets, showing W.P.A. employees engaged in street improvements. Note on the right, the City Theatre, located on the south side of East 14th Street, between Third and Fourth Aves. Shown in the center of the view are the lower
stories of the Consolidated Edison Co. Building.
September 2, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

711230f-a.text:
East 14th Street, st, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Irving Place (left), showing prominently the original Academy of Music, built in 1854 as a permanent home for Italian opera. It opened on October 2nd of that year, with a performance of Norma, by the Griel and Mario Company. Interior deserting by fire, May 22, 1866.

Between 1854-66

Gift of Urbrock Collection
NEG #1308
